reviewText:
From the same developers as Toki Tori, their talent with creating tricky but doable puzzles is still readily apparent. I am not at all a fan of puzzle games as I get frustrated very quickly, so the fact I finished this one is probably everything a fan of the genre needs to know.

Gameplay is deceptively simple- use redirectional tiles to guide a series of coloured blocks home. If you've seen the trailer, you already know everything you need to know in order to start playing. The layouts are fiendish though, and tease you with making it very clear what you HAVE to do, but keeping HOW to do it closely guarded. Many of the puzzles are forehead-slappingly clear once you figure it out, but until you get to that point you'll be dazed and confused trying to figure out how you're supposed to get THIS block over THERE with two Turn Left tiles and a Stop tile.

Unfortunately the hardest levels tend to devolve into a confusing mess of tiles and blocks everywhere- while earlier levels it was clear where you were going wrong, later levels are so tightly packed it can be hard to figure out exactly what the problem with your solution is. However, the powerful in-built Hint system is tremendously helpful in untying these knots, and perhaps borders on being TOO helpful if you allow it to be- one button tells you if the tiles you have placed should be where they are or not, the other reveals the correct location of every tile you have (but not while tile to put in that place). With trial and error these hints can pretty much solve the puzzle for you, so stay strong-willed and only use it when you're completely against the wall!

reviewText:
I bought this game on sale for very cheap, and while I can't say it's not worth what I paid, because it most certainly is, I just think there was a lot of wasted potential here. The thing is, puzzles in general can be very fun and rewarding, or very frustrating. I think the main thing that makes a puzzle frustrating is when you simply don't have enough information to solve it. Sure, it's a valuable life skill to be able to solve problems even when you don't have all the tools, but those kinds of problems are supposed to give you real life rewards, not present themselves as games and take your money.

My biggest complaint about this game is that it relies heavily on things it never gives you a chance to understand, particularly timing. Many of the puzzles are very simple in a spatial sense, but require timing movements exactly so that you can interweave block paths. However, the game doesn't let you change the speed of the runs, and it's not consistent between different runs. Furthermore, some of the harder puzzles have blocks traveling at different speeds.

As if that wasn't enough, it seems the game doesn't even judge collisions based on a notion of which block occupies which tile, but rather it actually uses hit detection, so blocks entering and leaving a tile at about the same time can still collide by touching corners for a split second. This makes some of the puzzles unnecessarily trial-and-error in nature, with the player just switching blocks around between multiple nearly identical solutions in spatial terms which result in slightly different timing, in the hopes that one of them will eventually produce the correct result. A good puzzle game shouldn't be designed to make you just randomly try things until one works.

Another complain I have is that there's no ability to zoom the camera in or out as far as I can tell. You can rotate the camera, but the level of zoom is consistently too close or far to clearly see all of the map. The game would've also benefitted from a square lense (orthogonal view if I remember correctly from 3D modeling) rather than an eye-type lense, because several of the puzzles have you dropping blocks from one platform down to another below it, and trying to line up the camera from above to see what will happen isn't very effective.



All in all, it's an interesting concept for a game that had potential, but it feels like it was developed to work against you and force you into trial-and-error runs rather than actually thinking about space and time in discrete units with well-defined, known rates of movement. This game could've been more fun in 2D 20 years ago. I found myself using the hints (which make it way too easy) and trial-and-error to solve the harder puzzles, because it didn't even feel like cheating when that's about what I would do without the hints anyway.

reviewText:
'RUSH' is a casual puzzle game with multiple coloured cubes.

Desc:
Your goal is to guide the cubes from their spawn point to their designated exit point. Red cubes have to be guided from the red spawn to the red exit point, blue cubes .. etc. You have a certain amount of placeable objects in each level to solve the puzzle. There are objects like a stop sign, where the cubes will pause their movement for a second or arrow signs, where the cubes will change their direction. The level will fail, if one the cubes falls of the platform, cubes will crash together or cubes won't get to the right exit.

Pros:
+ Easy to get into.
+ Nice soundtrack.
+ Three different chapters of difficulty and one bonus chapter.
+ Tutorial chapter. (Not really needed except the fact that cubes at walls will turn 90° to the right.)
+ Hint system for inexperienced gamers. (I never used this option.)
(+ nice to see cubes rolling to their designated point like a working machine)
(+ downloadable demo)
(+ steam achievements)

Cons:
- You can't speed up the rolling sequence of the cubes.
- You can't zoom with the camera.
- You can't hide planes of the platform!!! (Some levels are cramped and you have to adjust the camera like crazy!)
- There are always to much cubes that will spawn. (I don't know why the devs have implemented so much spawning cubes for the levels. It would be enough if there would spawn 4 cubes of each colour.)

Recommended, but only if it's on sale, because of the short game duration, the small amount of levels, the easy difficulty and of the (IMHO) annoying cons.

@Devs: One good patch that would patch the cons would rise the rating enormous.

@Gamers: Play the game 'EDGE' (same dev studio) it's definitely much better than 'RUSH'.

6.5/10

reviewText:
RUSH is a 3D indie puzzle game by Two Tribes[twotribes.com]. It's their second Windows release after the successful Toki Tori. In RUSH, the player needs to guide colored cubes to the appropriate exit points. This happens by using items that are unlocked through the progress of the game, such as Conveyor belts, Warps and more. The player places the items in advance and needs to imagine how they will affect the cubes' process through the level.

I don't have much to say against this game, just one suggestion: a level editor would be great. After completing this game once, I have nothing more to do and there's no motivation for me to play it anymore. If there was an option to download community-created levels (for example through the Steam Workshop) and designing own levels, it would definitely raise the replay potential for me and probably many other players.

Other than that, this game has great, tricky levels, for those who want a challenge, or if you want to set your mind at ease or are just stuck at one level for a while, there's a hint system that makes your life easier. The environment looks neat and clean, which contributes to the game's calming and relaxing feel along with a chill music and simple drag and drop controls. Everything about this game says No rush." reviewText: This is a good mind-bendy puzzle game. You need to think in different ways to solve all the different levels. Quite a few hours if you want to do all of them, and more again if you want to go for all the achievements.

A must have for any puzzler enthusiast's collection.

RUSH is a 3d puzzle game involving simple logic skills. There's colored entrances and exits, and as soon as you believe you've finished the puzzle, blocks will teleport into existence and follow a straight line across the map, only turning right when they bump into walls.

You, as the player, have to place special movement pads on the ground that influence the path these blocks take, allowing you to divert block traffic to help all of them reach the exit without colliding or falling off the map.

While this premise sounds really simple, in practice it can get really complex because of this simplicity. There's 4 direction changing pads, a direction switcher that switches back and forth when blocks use it. A pause pad, as well as a conveyor belt pad. While their effects are simple, it's the entire contraption and combination of switching and redirecting traffic at the right place that turns out to be the big puzzling question in this game.

The game divides the puzzles in a few difficulty settings, starting with tutorial/easy puzzles that only involve a few pads, up to hard and 'special' puzzles that require great insights and rational systematic analysis of the paths the cubes take to find out the solution. As such, pretty much anyone should be able to get *something* out of this game, and the more you practice, the better you'll get, allowing even the weaker puzzle fanatic to grow and progress to the harder areas of the game.

RUSH also features a slightly upbeat ambient track that is fun to listen to, and it really fits with the sounds of blocks squeaking their way throughout the level.

So if you like puzzles, if you like 3d puzzles, if you like logical thinking. Get this game! It's definitely worth the price.

As a sidenote, if you liked Chu Chu Rocket: This is the exact same thing, except it uses cubes.

Sound: 3/5
The sounds are simple but fitting, though some people might get tired of the Sqeaky Cube noise after a while.

Graphics: 3/5
The graphics are again, simple, but fitting. Everything is cube shaped and the ambient lighting gives the entire game a soft look and feel. The cubes themselves are a bit more shiny. There's not much to say due to the simple graphics, but they look good for a puzzle game.

Gameplay: 4/5
Great puzzle fun, though there's less replay value once you've finished them all, unless you forget the solutions to the old ones. Controls are fluent, game mechanics are simple to understand and logical.

Overall: 4/5
It just works, the amount of content you get for the low price is great, the gameplay is fun, and everything just blends together into one great game.

RUSH is a decent puzzle game suffering from some interface issues. Gameplay is quite simple, and unlimited hints allow anyone to progress through the game. The main problem is that you will likely spend more time rotating the camera to the correct angle rather than thinking about the puzzles. I feel like this camera issue is almost by design, as later levels push the designs to obscure as much of the layout as possible. It's a simple puzzle game without clarity in many levels. Interestingly, some puzzle elements are barely utilized or introduced (speed up/down modifiers), but the game is most certainly not getting updates to add levels using these elements.

reviewText:
Presentation
Originally a WiiWare download title called Rubik's Puzzle Galaxy: Rush, the game has since lost its Rubik's licence, being released on Steam simply as Rush, with additional stages and content. Rush is a puzzle game, in which you are given a certain number of directional signs, stop signs or split signs which you can place on the map in order to guide each cube from point A to point B without them colliding or falling off the map. Those stages are grouped based on their difficulty starting with the easy ones, and moving on to the medium ones and the hard ones, allowing you to choose a challenge fit for your experience and get better with time, allowing you to learn from your mistakes, observe how the cubes move once you've hit the green button and rearrange the signs based on what you have seen. There is no sense of advancement since there is no leveling up system and you're not really unlocking anything besides the next levels, but playing Rush more will definitely make you better at it, as long as you keep replaying the same stage, since you're not exactly learning how to play the game better, but instead observing the problems in your sign arrangement; it's more like ruling out the bad solution and eventually getting to the right one, how long it takes to get there depends only on how well you understand the mechanics.
Rating: 7

Gameplay
The gameplay is simplistic and intuitive, offering a challenge for everyone and satisfaction to those who dare to give the hardest levels a shot. Placing signs is easy and understanding how they work is the key to solving puzzles, while directional signs are the most encountered ones, using them efficiently is what will get you through as the natural direction of the cube plays an important role in many puzzles, and combining good use of direction movement with things such as speed which can be influenced using a stop sign or a directional sign, and the split sign which will allow you to group cubes based on their color in order to send them in the right direction, all matters in the end. There is also a hint system that will tell you where signs should be placed without giving the exact order, a tool that will come in handy for those who want to enjoy the game without wasting too much time on a single puzzle. There are levels grouped depending on the challenge level, but there's nothing stopping you from enjoying all of them, as the hard ones can be approached using the hint system and the easy ones can be fun even for the pros. Adding all that up, there are more than 80 different stages, with different levels of difficulty, so there's plenty of challenge for everyone.
Rating: 7.5

Graphics
Rush is a colorful universe, using cubes and their respective colors to create beautiful backgrounds that will often captivate you more than the stage itself. Even though all the stages respect the same rules of color and formation, each one feels unique in its own way, and successfully solving a puzzle often rewards you with a beautiful parade of flawlessly moving blocks.
Rating: 7

Audio
The electronic soundtrack is in theme with the game, and even though the number of tracks is limited and will become repetitive eventually, you can always play Rush with your own music in the background since there is no dialogue or information given that you'll miss if you do that. The sound effects are okay, yet nothing spectacular to support the colorful movement of successfully guided blocks.
Rating: 6.5

Extras
With all its 80+ stages including the bonus stages and the special Portal Event stages, Rush can take anywhere from 3 hours to 10 hours to complete, depending how long it takes for you to give up and hit the hint button, but even so for a 5 bucks title, you get plenty of content to play around with.
Rating: 7.5

Verdict
Rush is a must play for puzzle fans who want a little challenge, but it still provides a few intriguing levels for the casual puzzle solvers too, so there are enough reasons for everyone to give it a shot and see how well they can guide the cubes.
Rating Overall: 7.1

Check out the full review and a lot more about RUSH at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=355

reviewText: Rush is a 3D puzzle game that requires high level perception as well as cognitive thinking to solve its overabundance of puzzles. In rush you used direction tiles as well as other types to guide cubes to exits. One of the top reason to buy Rush is the fact that there is no competition in this game. There is no clock to time you, there are no scores to obtain, it’s just your mind against puzzles. All these factors combined with a very soothing tune and you’re in for a very zen-like period while playing. This game hits perfection almost everywhere, the pacing is fantastic, the controls are intuitive, and the art direction is very relevant to the game. However, the game completely lacks replayability and all the puzzles have very limited solutions. This is because each puzzles have a fixed amount of tiles and in almost every scenario in Rush, you will end up using them all. Regardless, the game is very high quality and for such a cheap price replayability is a non-issue.

RUSH is one of those games that sneaks up on you in terms of difficulty. It starts out simply enough- here's some cubes, get them to the exit, here's some arrows to make them go in directions. By the time you realize it, you're threading slower-moving cubes between waves of advancing ones with precision timing, tossing cubes down holes with no visible exit, teleporting around with wild abandon, and even solving a puzzle in complete darkness (check the bonus levels, it's really there). If you like puzzle games, give this a shot, if only for the catchy soundtrack.

Heck, if you're going to get it, go for the whole Two Tribes pack and enjoy Toki Tori and EDGE with it.

PROS:
Great soundtrack
Difficulty scales up nicely over time
Hints for those puzzles you just can't figure out
Cheap

CONS:
No hints for the Actual Challenge levels (but then again, this was part of the Potato Sack ARG, so that would make it too easy.)
Limited replay value (unless you really want to shoot for cheevos)
Get Rush if you love puzzle games, it will keep yout hinking for hours

If anyone remembers Chu Chu Rocket for the Dreamcast, then RUSH plays in a similar fashion: You guide colored cubes to their respective exits by placing directional switches on the field without having the cubes bump into each other or driving them off the playing area.

While the concept may sound simple enough, the difficulty is all in the level design. In order to successfully pass the later levels, one must master the nuances of the cubes movements as it interects with the directional tiles and field obstacles as a majority of the puzzles require the user to time the cubes actions accordingly.

All in all, it's a fun little game for the brain.

RUSH is a very clever puzzle game. You place a variety of markers trying to direct moving, coloured cubes to their goal. If the cubes collide with a wall they will turn to the right, if they collide with each other or fall off the stage then you lose. It sounds simple but the developers have created many great puzzles that may even take hours to solve. If you like a mental challenge then this is a game for you.

A good way to describe RUSH would be to say that it's a cross between SpaceChem and EDGE (except, of course, that it predates both of those games). It has a similar emphasis as the former on what's essentially visual programming, and also features the latter's basic gameplay mechanic of cubes rolling around on a 3-dimensional playing field. The result is an enjoyable puzzle game that can keep you occupied for hours. While the puzzles are much less open-ended than the ones in SpaceChem and thus provide less replay value, the solutions can, at times, provide considerable satisfaction from just looking at them, with large numbers of colourful cubes rolling around in sync with each other. Recommended for all puzzle game fans.

RUSH is a solid puzzle game, unique in the way that each one needs to be. The basic mechanic of using directional and other controlling pads to direct blocks of various colors toward their respective goals is an intelligent and compelling one, if slightly more so on paper than when playing. I give my compliments to the developers for wringing as much life as they have with RUSH out of a few simple pad types: up, down, left, right (no cheating - the pads rotate in tandem as you rotate the camera), alternate-direction (this one's my favorite, particularly with the puzzles that having blocks approach the pad from different directions creates), conveyor (shifts a block over one space while preserving its direction), and temporary-stop. Use of warp points, while a bit of a design crutch, adds more variety so I'll give it a pass. The game does get tedious, though, when you have to fine-tune your pathways so that blocks don't run into one another. In moderation this would add welcome depth to the gameplay, but as it is, it shifts the balance a little too far from creative problem-solving to drudging trial-and-error. Another, less frequently visible flaw in the game mechanics is that the number of blocks you must allow through your system is inconsistent - I once noticed that, due to the way I had my alternate-direction pads set up, my solution wouldn't have worked if one more block of each color had been expelled. The general feeling of designing cycles, however, is quite relaxing, so the gameplay is still well in the positive zone in my eyes.\n\nThere's not much to be said about the aesthetics. The music, while extremely repetitive, somehow scarcely gets annoying. The visuals... exist. My only complaints tangent to a discussion of aesthetics here concern the camera: you can't zoom, and the overhead expanse of blocks in the crocodile" (or was it "alligator"?) level is a needless hindrance. Not impossible to work around

The only complaint would be like others have said and that's the fact that a number of achievements are not possible anymore or restricted to certain months.
